description: From Middle English arriven, ariven, a borrowing from Old French ariver, from Late Latin *arrīpare, from Latin ad + rīpa (“shore”). Displaced native oncome, tocome.
For the sense-derivation, compare Old English ġelandian, ġelendan, lendan (“to arrive at land; land”) > Middle English alenden, landen (“to arrive; arrive at shore; land”).

verbs.description: arrive (third-person singular simple present arrives, present participle arriving, simple past and past participle arrived)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, copulative) To reach; to get to a certain place.
examples: We arrived at the hotel and booked in.
He arrived home for two days.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To obtain a level of success or fame; to succeed.
examples: He had finally arrived on Broadway.
The time has arrived for us to depart.
Happy! to whom this glorious death arrives.

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To reach; to come to.

examples: and made the sea-trod ship arrive them
